Award.AwardTitle: Massively Parallel Nanolithography Using Localized Electron Emission

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Optical lithography is the critical enabling process of transferring fixed geometric patterns on a mask to wafers to make semiconductor chips and other nanotechnology products. Current tools cost more than 50 million US dollars each, and the costs for masks far outweigh those for tools. Yet, to increase chip capabilities to match Moore's law, tools will soon become too costly for both industry and scientists. Also, the current process cannot meet the long-term demand to produce faster chips with more functions. This award supports fundamental research to provide needed knowledge for the development of a new lithography technology. Results from this research will strengthen the U.S. manufacturing foundation for future information-technology growth and profoundly impact applications in high-performance computing, data storage, communications, healthcare and energy. This award will help broaden participation of underrepresented groups in engineering research and create an education pipeline in a multidisciplinary and collaborative environment.

Scanning electron beam writers can direct pattern semiconductor chips at very high resolution without the need of expensive photomasks but only in low throughput. Practical throughput is possible only by using millions of parallel electron beams. Researchers have been unable to find a robust method to generate a massive number of beams with satisfactory brightness and uniformity. This research is to address this challenge and enable massively-parallel electron-beam lithography by transforming the team's recent breakthroughs in nanoscale optics into a low-cost nanomanufacturing scheme. This technology uses a novel device to focus optical energy at nanoscale and locally excite electrons to form massively-parallel electron beams, which can be used to perform maskless lithography in mass quantities. The research team will investigate the fundamentals of localized electron excitation, build a proof-of-concept device and study device response, and implement the device into their scalable nanomanufacturing platforms to demonstrate lithography over a large area.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Similar to an optical image projection, optical lithography projects geometric patterns from a mask onto silicon wafers to make semiconductor chips and other nanotechnology products, such as personal computers and smartphones. Current lithography tools cost more than 50 million US dollar each, and the costs for masks far outweigh those for tools. Yet, to increase chip capabilities to match Moore's law, the future generation tools will cost more than 100s of million US dollar each. This award supports fundamental research to provide needed knowledge for the development of an alternative lithography method. The high cost of optical lithography is fundamentally caused by the large wavelength of the light beams. The electron beams can also pattern semiconductor chips. Because electron beams have much smaller wavelengths, they can write nanoscale patterns at very high resolution. However, individual electron beam can only provide a very low throughput. A practically-high throughput is possible only by using millions of electron beams in parallel. In this NSF project, the team addressed this challenge and enabled the massive number of electron beams for parallel writing. The team invented a novel device to focus optical energy at nanoscale and locally excite electrons to form massively-parallel electron beams (Image 1), which can be used to perform lithography in mass quantities without the need of expensive photomasks. During the life of this NSF Award, the research team investigated the fundamentals of localized electron excitation from the plasmonic focusing lenses (Image 2), design and fabricated a proof-of-concept device capable of generating over 1 million electron beams (Image 3), study device response and implement the device into their prototype lithography system (Image 4) to demonstrate lithography. The research team have successfully demonstrated the patterning at a 22-nm resolution in a university laboratory setting, which promises sub-10 nm features for high-volume nanomanufacturing in industrial applications.

Intellectual Merit: This proposed technology provided an alternative route to meet the needs of high-volume nanomanufacturing of demanding products such as high-performance computer and high-capacity data storage.  The immediate research outcomes included the novel nanolithography platforms, new multiphysics modeling tools and experimental techniques for studying the device, and general methods for design and implementation of nanomanufacturing processes. In addition, this technology can also serve as a novel platform to explore the use of electron beam in imaging, characterization, and materials processing.

Broader Impacts: Results from this research also helped to strengthen the U.S. manufacturing foundation for future information-technology growth, and directly and indirectly impacted many technological areas. Another important aspect of this work is to create an education pipeline for nanomanufacturing in a multidisciplinary and collaborative environment.  Through the integration of research and education, the project provided trainings of high-tech workforce in nanomanufacturing, and reach out to the underrepresented populations.  Also many undergraduate students participated in this research through the NSF's REU program and independent study programs.  The Award also helped the research team to actively engage in nanotechnology education for K-12 groups.  Results of the project have been broadly disseminated through scientific publications, participations at meetings of professional societies.
